snippet: In the third year of the IHT's groundbreaking and sweeping series on women, we ask what comes next in the developed and developing world. Can young women in the West really have it all? Or do their sisters in the dynamic developing world have some...
lead_paragraph: The Female Factor is the IHT's look at the place of women in the early 21st century. Many women have more power over their bodies and their fates than at any time in history. What are they doing with this new-found influence? Where do they want to go? This year, the third of this uniquely broad and thorough series on the world's women, we will paint ''Womenscapes,'' portraits that illustrate the vast possibilities - and the limitations - in a world that has now largely embraced women's empowerment as a positive force.
abstract: In the third year of the IHT's groundbreaking and sweeping series on women, we ask what comes next in the developed and developing world. Can young women in the West really have it all? Or do their sisters in the dynamic developing world have some advantages?

headline.main: Womenscapes

snippet: To The Living Section:   I would like to clarify the quotation from me in your piece headlined "Bodies Go Public: It's Men's Turn Now" on Oct. 31. I am quoted as saying, "Taboos preserve the sense of special mystery of one gender as opposed to ano...
lead_paragraph: To The Living Section: I would like to clarify the quotation from me in your piece headlined "Bodies Go Public: It's Men's Turn Now" on Oct. 31. I am quoted as saying, "Taboos preserve the sense of special mystery of one gender as opposed to another" and thus "contribute to equality." Public displays and open discussion of male or female sexuality contribute to equality only if men and women participate equally. Formerly, displays of the female form underscored that men had the distinct power to look while women were looked upon, thus contributing to inequality . The new trend toward the unveiling of men's bodies means that both men and women are eqally open (or closed) to each other. This is why (as the next sentence properly says) the breakdown of taboos against display of the male body speaks to equality between the sexes. TODD GITLIN Professor of Sociology University of California Berkeley, Calif.

headline.main: Taboos and Sexuality

snippet: A proposal to set a quota for female candidates on party parliamentary slates is being linked to the economic mess that a largely male leadership led the country into, reports Didi Kirsten Tatlow in her Page Two column....
lead_paragraph: CORK, Ireland - Since the economic meltdown that began in 2009 with the bursting of the Irish property bubble, unemployment has risen to more than 14 percent and the national debt to €120 billion, or $159 billion - an almost cartoonishly large sum for a nation of 4.6 million people.
abstract: A proposal to set a quota for female candidates on party parliamentary slates is being linked to the economic mess that a largely male leadership led the country into, reports Didi Kirsten Tatlow in her Page Two column.

headline.main: Would Women Have Spared Ireland?

snippet: To the Editor:   Re "Era of Female Combat Pilots Opens With Shrugs and Glee" (front page, April 29): The "jubilation" over the inclusion of women in flying combat roles, this "leap into the next century" for women's rights, is in order. It is an o...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Era of Female Combat Pilots Opens With Shrugs and Glee" (front page, April 29): The "jubilation" over the inclusion of women in flying combat roles, this "leap into the next century" for women's rights, is in order. It is an overdue legal achievement worth celebrating, insofar as the piloting ability of women is concerned. But one fundamental point seems to be missed.

headline.main: Equality With What?
